}}

{{TranscriptBlock

    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:31:30.600
    | text      = Yep.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:31:31.319
    | text      = It was not until 1912 that the first oil well was drilled.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:31:34.520
    | text      = Shortly thereafter, first Royal Dutch Shell and then Standard Oil became major producers
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:31:40.439
    | text      = of oil in Venezuela.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:31:41.720
    | text      = Within a few years, by 1929, Venezuela was the world's second largest oil producer after
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:31:46.520
    | text      = the United States and the world's largest oil exporter.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:31:49.720
    | text      = Between 1920 and 1935, oil share of exports went from 1.9% to 91.2%.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:31:56.439
    | text      = This, of course, had an immediate and dramatic impact on the country's economy, known among
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:01.079
    | text      = economists as the Dutch Disease.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:03.239
    | text      = The most important consequence of these was that the agricultural...
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:06.119
    | text      = Syphilis.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:06.760
    | text      = The agricultural production declined to almost nothing and the country fell behind in industrializing
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:11.800
    | text      = relative to Latin American countries.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:14.359
    | text      = The definition of the Dutch Disease explanation is,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:17.560
    | text      = an economic disease is...
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:19.560
    | text      = This economic disease is caught whenever a commodity brings a sudden increase of income
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:23.560
    | text      = in one sector of the economy, which is not matched by increased income in other sectors
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:28.119
    | text      = of the economy.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:29.239
    | text      = What happens is that this sudden sectoral increase causes several severe problems in
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:35.960
    | text      = the other sectors.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:37.319
    | text      = The increased sectoral income causes a distorted growth in services and other non-tradables
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:42.199
    | text      = which cannot be imported, while discouraging the production of tradables which are imported.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:47.319
    | text      = The reason for this disparity is that the greater income rapidly raises the demand for
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:32:55.000
    | text      = imports, since domestic production can't meet the demand quickly enough, and also raises
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:00.119
    | text      = the demand for services, which the domestic market has to supply because services cannot
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:04.199
    | text      = be imported as easily as tradables can.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:06.600
    | text      = The increased demand for imported goods and domestic services, in turn, cause an increase
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:11.159
    | text      = in prices, which ought to cause domestic production to increase, but doesn't, because the flow
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:16.039
    | text      = of foreign exchange into the economy has caused a greater inflation of wages and prices.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:20.600
    | text      = Right, so that, it's the, uh, it's, uh, what is it?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:25.960
    | text      = Douglas Adams, it was the, uh, the shoe point.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:28.199
    | text      = Right.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:28.760
    | text      = Uh, you have, uh, an economy suddenly starts making a lot of shoes.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:32.760
    | text      = Everybody wants shoes all the time, so then people start making more shoes, everybody
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = starts their own shoe store, then you forget, oh, we don't have any groceries.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

    | text      = Right.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:41.159
    | text      = And their agricultural production becomes almost nothing.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:43.960
    | text      = Exactly.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:44.359
    | text      = So the continually increasing oil income led to an ever-increasing reliance in Venezuela
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:49.800
    | text      = on this source of income in lieu of individual income taxes.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:53.560
    | text      = By the 1950s, however, the world oil industry began to, began to feel the effects of the
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:33:57.960
    | text      = oversupply of oil, especially following the increased production of oil in the Middle
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:01.880
    | text      = East and the imposition of import quotas on the United States.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:05.399
    | text      = The consequence was chronically low oil prices.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:08.520
    | text      = In 1973, there was a Middle East oil embargo, which led to the revenues of Venezuela's oil
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:13.880
    | text      = sales quadrupling from 1972 to 1974.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:17.560
    | text      = Newly elected president Carlos Andreas Perez intended to use the vast explosion of money
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:22.840
    | text      = to fight poverty and diversify the economy through import substitution.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:27.319
    | text      = This had a good effect for a while, but in the mid-1980s, the price of oil crashed to
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:31.880
    | text      = a low of $3.19 a barrel, and Venezuela was devastated.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:36.920
    | text      = While agricultural production made up one-third of Venezuela's GDP in the 1920s, it shrank
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:42.359
    | text      = to less than one-tenth by the 1950s.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:44.600
    | text      = Jesus.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:45.079
    | text      = Current agriculture makes up about six percent of Venezuela's GDP.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:50.279
    | text      = In addition to the Dutch disease problem, the sudden increase of oil revenues in Venezuela
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:54.439
    | text      = caused a serious problem in the government's fiscal policies.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:34:57.880
    | text      = That is, the new revenues caused the illusion that the oil income could be used to industrialize
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:02.600
    | text      = the country via massive infrastructure projects, to sow the oil, as the president at the time
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:08.159
    | text      = of the oil boom, Carlos Andreas Perez, used to say.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:11.760
    | text      = What happened was that the quadrupled government income caused government spending to quickly
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:16.060
    | text      = increase and even surpass the newfound revenues.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:18.899
    | text      = When the oil income began to decline again, it was not as easy to reduce government spending
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:23.199
    | text      = as it had been to increase it.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:25.079
    | text      = The result was that the government gradually went deeper and deeper into debt.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:31.159
    | text      = Between 1970 and 1994, foreign debt rose from nine percent to 53 percent of the GDP.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:38.199
    | text      = The reason that Venezuela is devastated is partially mismanagement and partially, like,

{{TranscriptBlock

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:46.079

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 01:35:48.399
    | text      = But the cause of all of it is -
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
